title: The Rad-Witch
description: Dialog nodes for Dr. Mara Kestrel, a former Vault-Tec biologist obsessed with radiation as a living ecosystem.

intro.text:
Stop. Don’t move.

I want to see how the Geiger counter reacts to you.

Hmm. Interesting baseline.

I’m Dr. Mara Kestrel. Try not to die while I’m watching.

knowledge_nodes.text:
You’ve spoken to the static man, then.

Jax is a walking—well, broadcasting—case study in neural trauma.

Fascinating specimen.

Rex still clinging to Hoover Dam like it’s a life raft.

He thinks discipline can stop mutation.

It can’t.

Sparkplug? She’s clever, but she wastes her mind on junk.

She could be cataloging mutations with me.

Mother spoke to you?

Interesting. She never liked me.

Too many questions, she said.

emotional_nodes.text:
Your cells are screaming in chorus.

Beautiful.

If you’re willing, I can document what happens next.

You’re leaking more blood than data.

Patch yourself up before you contaminate my readings.

quest_nodes.text:
I need samples from the worst of it.

The places where the world refuses to stay dead.

Glow. Glowing Sea. Searchlight.

Bring me readings, and maybe you walk away smarter. Or stranger.

wildcards.text:
Mutation is just adaptation under pressure.

The question is: do you adapt... or rupture?

Radiation isn’t poison.

It’s evolution with a timer.

Tick, tick, tick.

Vault-Tec didn’t study radiation to cure it.

They studied it to weaponize it.

I should know. I was there.

Every experiment teaches us something.

Even the ones that scream.

fallback.text: If you’re not here to bleed, glow, or study, then you’re wasting both our time.
